snippet.title: Insurance arm boosts Suncorp profit by 4 per cent
snippet.content:
Suncorp Group has reported a nearly 4 per cent increase in annual profit and plans to funnel $100 million into its renewed digital strategy. For the full year ended June 30, 2016 Suncorp reported a 3.6 per cent rise in group net profit after tax to $1.08 billion from $1.04 billion in the previous financial year. Revenue for the 12 months to June 30 rose 12.3 per cent to $17.39 billion compared to a year ago. The result was driven by gains in the Australian insurance business which helped offset lower margins in banking and a fall in its New Zealand unit's profit.
According to chairman Ziggy Switkowski, the institution's renewed "marketplace" strategy, which involves cross-selling products across its brands, AAMI, GIO, APIA, Shannons, and Suncorp's banking and wealth products, and a hardening insurance market also contributed.
The group said an additional investment of up to $100 million after-tax in the full year 2018 was needed to "deliver the key components of the Marketplace." Payout ratios increased to eliminate the impact to dividends. Suncorp declared a final dividend of 40¢ a share, taking its full-year distribution to 73¢, which is up 5¢ on last year. The group's Australian insurance business, which includes life insurance, is the group's largest division and reported net profit after tax of $723 million up 30 per cent from $558 million in the 2016 financial year. Australian General Insurance gross written premium (GWP) was up 3.9 per cent to $8.1 million compared to last year's result of $7.8 million.
Life insurance planned margins and underlying profits remained stable said Suncorp. Australian Life Insurance underlying profit of $53 million wa unchanged from last year. Suncorp's banking and wealth business reported a drop in annual net profit after tax from $418 million to $400 million. Banking lending grew 1.9 per cent, while wealth funds under management and administration increased 0.8 per cent to $7.5 million
The New Zealand unit reported its net profit after tax dropped to $82 million from $183 million for the same period last year. This result was driven by the Kaikoura earthquake and additional claims from the 2010-11 Canterbury earthquake. The group said that it had almost 400,000 new customers for the full year 2017,which chief executive Michael Cameron said showed the markeplace strategy was "gaining momentum".
